resources.string: Emissions of different heating technologies per year

• Heat pumps are by far the most efficient heating technology.
• They convert 1 kWh of electricity into 3 to 4 kWh of heat on average.
• Ground-source heat pumps offer greater efficiency than air-source ones, but at higher installation costs.
• Fridges and freezers use the same thermodynamic process as a heat pump, moving heat from inside the appliance to the outside.
• Sources: Prof. Dipl. ‚ÄìIng. W. Schenk, Hochschule M√ºnchen, 2020 and Greenhouse Media GmbH, 2022 (accessed on 14.04.2025).

• In the EU, the main use of energy by households is for residential heating, followed by water heating.
• In 2022, the residential sector accounted for 26% of the total final energy consumption in the EU.
• Source: Eurostat, 2024 (accessed on 14.04.2025).

• Replacing fossil-fuel heating with a heat pump can significantly reduce CO‚ÇÇ emissions.
• Powered by renewables, heat pumps emit almost no greenhouse gases‚Äîemissions drop further as renewable grid share rises.
• Source: Bundesverband W√§rmepumpe (BWP) e.V., 2024 (accessed on 14.04.2025).

• Heat pumps support grid stability by flexibly balancing supply and demand‚Äîespecially with smart grid technologies.
• Heat pumps shift energy use by storing heat when renewable generation is high and using it during peak demand.
• By shifting their energy consumption, heat pumps can effectively relieve the load on the electricity grid and reduce the need for grid expansion.
• Source: Fraunhofer IEE - Flexible W√§rmepumpen im Verteilnetz, 2022 (accessed on 14.04.2025).
